In the specific praise, there are four meanings, three meanings, two meanings, one meaning, and no meaning.

The fundamental, next praises the Dharma body.

As for the sequence of these three, there are three aspects to birth and death, namely retribution, karma, and afflictions, in sequence;

As for the two meanings, although there are three virtues, they do not go beyond two meanings:

As for the single meaning, having no afflictions that are not exhausted cannot be said to be existence, and having no virtues that are not perfected cannot be said to be nonexistence, which is called the middle way.

If one understands this meaning, then one can recognize the meaning of this text.
Now, I will explain it based on the three virtues. The first two verses praise the Dharma body, the next verse praises liberation, and the last verse praises prajÃ±Ä.
The three dharmas of the Nirvana Sutra take liberation as the first, the Dharma body as the next, and prajÃ±Ä as the last.

However, there are three different explanations of the three virtues in the south of the Yangtze River.
The first is Master Yun's explanation:

As for the meaning of non-existence, it is precisely in stillness that there is movement, although true it is the response, it is precisely in movement that there is stillness, although responding it is the truth.

As for the second gate of correct explanation, the ancient masters explained the sequential arising.
As for the wonderful form body of the TathÄgata, since one has already seen the golden countenance, therefore one praises the wonderful form first.

None in the world can equal it means there is nothing that can be the same as it, thus it is said to be unequaled.

The reason for inexhaustibility is because the basis is inexhaustible, therefore the response is always inexhaustible;

Now praising wisdom, the meaning should also be so, but it only briefly shows that wisdom is the same as form.

Question:

In this way, when Shengman has not yet become a Buddha, the sentient beings he transforms who cultivate wholesome roots will be reborn in his land when Shengman later becomes a Buddha.

Moreover, Mahayana sentient beings in other world systems, seeing and hearing that in Shengman's land only the Mahayana is taught, therefore make vows to be reborn there. Sentient beings like this vow to be reborn in the lands of AmitÄbha, Aká¹£obhya Buddha, and so forth.
Moreover, the above clearly explained the Pure Land's refinement and subtlety. At that time, the assembly may think it is difficult to be reborn there.
Now, wishing to lead them, if one changes evil and cultivates goodness, one will surely be reborn there.
The Lady Shengman and below. The above has clarified the bestowal of predictions. Now, the second is the great assembly vowing to be reborn.
The text is divided into two parts:
First, correctly vowing to be reborn;
The World-Honored One fully predicted - below this is the second point, clarifying that the Buddha granted predictions according to their wishes.
The reason for bestowing predictions is precisely for this meaning.
The reason why the Buddha predicted this is to encourage the beings going to be reborn to move towards the Pure Land.
At that time, ÅšrÄ«mÄlÄ - above this point clarifies the chapter on praising the TathÄgata's true and ultimate merits and virtues.
Now, it clarifies the acceptance of the ten great precepts, which can be explained in ten aspects:
1. The aspect of the purpose.
The previous chapter praises the Buddha and clarifies the arising of the bodhi mind. Now, it clarifies the cultivation of bodhisattva practices next.
The practices of bodhisattvas take the cessation of evil as the basis, so it clarifies the acceptance of precepts first.
This is a pair: the bodhi mind and bodhisattva practices.
2. The previous chapter praises the Buddha's true merits and virtues and requests protection, while this clarifies taking refuge in the Buddha.
Since taking refuge is completed, it next clarifies the acceptance of precepts.
This is a pair: taking refuge and precepts.
Third, praising the Buddha's true virtues above, this merit is already established, and will surely attract future fruits, so the Buddha immediately bestows the prediction of Buddhahood.
The Buddha has already predicted the future fruit, and this future fruit cannot be attained without practice.
The practitioner does not stop at any evil, does not fail to practice any good, and does not fail to liberate any person.
Above it clarifies the future fruit, now it distinguishes the causal practice, which is a pair of cause and effect.
Fourth, above it clarifies the Pure Land has three aspects:
First, being free from defilements, second, having purity, and third, only good sentient beings coming to be born in that land.
Cessation of all evil leads to the fruit of a land free from defilements;
Cultivation of all good leads to the fruit of a land with purity;
Liberation of all people leads to only good sentient beings coming to be born in that land.
By accomplishing the above three meanings of the Pure Land, it clarifies the acceptance of the three precepts.
Fifth, according to the Ornament Scripture, it is said there are two foundations:
All sentient beings first enter the ocean of the Three Jewels, taking faith as the foundation;
Abiding in the Buddha's family, precepts are the basis.
Above, praising the Buddha and taking refuge is the basis of faith;
Now, wishing to be born in the Buddha's family, precepts are the basis, therefore, receiving precepts.
Sixth, the Nirvana Sutra says, All sentient beings have Buddha-nature and will all become Buddhas.
It is necessary to uphold the precepts, and then see the nature.
The precepts are what lead out the Buddha-nature, therefore, receiving the precepts.

Seventh, in the request for protection above, it says to make the Dharma seeds grow. Now, receiving the ten major precepts and so forth, this is the meaning of the Dharma seeds growing, therefore, there is the meaning of this chapter.

The second is the section on explaining the name. Based on the text below, it says inconceivable great precepts. The bodhisattva precepts are profound and vast, difficult to uphold and difficult to practice, not upheld by the two vehicles, therefore, it clarifies the inconceivable.
Moreover, not upholding and not violating is the correct Dharma precepts, called inconceivable.
As for the term great, first, it refers to the essence of greatness, which is to universally cease all evil, universally cultivate all good, and universally save all people.
Second, it refers to the fruit of attainment, which is the great sages, bodhisattvas, great human kings, and great heavenly kings.

Third, it is called great because it is practiced by great people. Among the nine paths, the six destinies and the two vehicles are all unable to practice it, only bodhisattvas can practice it, so it is called great.
Fourth, it refers to the greatness of time, which is to always uphold this precept for three great incalculably long eons.
Fifth, it is never lost. A precept for one day ends and then is gone;
a precept for one lifetime ends and then is extinguished.
If one receives the great bodhisattva precepts once, even though one goes through the six destinies, the precepts are not lost, so it is called great.
Master Fu said:
Respectfully receiving with an empty mind and strictly upholding, therefore it is called receiving.
Third, clarifying the different aspects of receiving precepts.
According to the Garland Sutra, there are three ways to receive the precepts:
First, in the presence of Buddhas and Bodhisattvas, one can receive the true and genuine precepts of the highest grade.

Second, after the passing of the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas, if there is a Bodhisattva who has already received the precepts within a thousand li, one can request him to be the Dharma teacher and instruct oneself in the precepts. One should first pay homage at his feet.
One should say:
I request the Venerable One to be my teacher and bestow the precepts upon me.
The disciple then receives the true Dharma precepts, which are the precepts of the middle grade.

Third, after the passing of the Buddha, if there is no Dharma teacher within a thousand li, one should kneel before the images of the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas, join palms, and vow to receive the precepts.
One should say:
I, so-and-so, declare to the Buddhas and great Bodhisattvas of the ten directions that I will study all the Bodhisattva precepts. This is the precepts of the lower grade.
This should be said a second and a third time.
Now ÅšrÄ«mÄlÄ is presently encountering the Buddha, which is the highest level, but it is only a self-vowed reception, not one bestowed by the Buddha.
But the second type of reception from a Dharma teacher has two kinds:

If based on the Ornament Scripture, the precept teacher does not perform the karman method. First, they are made to pay homage to all Buddhas of the past, next to the Buddhas of the future, and next to the Buddhas of the present.
Having paid homage in this way three times, it is the same for the Dharma and the Saá¹ƒgha.
Next, they are made to receive the precepts of the three refuges, next to repent of their offenses of the three periods of time, and then later the ten inexhaustible precepts areæ­£æˆã€‚
If like the Sutra on the Stages of the Bodhisattva, the bodhisattva precept teacher performs the karman in advance, and then bestows the precepts.
This is the preliminary expedient, not the actual bestowal of the precepts.
Also, like receiving the five precepts or ten precepts, after receiving the three refuges and the precepts are explained, one is then called a precept-holder.
This means that after receiving the three refuges and the precepts are explained, one obtains the precepts.
How do we know this?
It is like a person who directly receives the Three Refuges, who only obtains the refuges but not the precepts, or like the preliminary karman for receiving the great bhiká¹£u precepts.

Then the precepts have already been received. Later, the four grave offenses, etc., are explained, causing the recipient to uphold them firmly. Explaining the characteristics of the precepts is not for the purpose of receiving the precepts.
Based on this evidence, one should know that one must perform the karman beforehand in order to receive the precepts.

As for the lack of karman in the Ornament of the Scriptures and the Brahma's Net Sutra, it may be that it was omitted earlier, or it may be that the teaching methods are not fixed, and one should use them according to the time.
Question:
For the bodhisattva precept master, are they a layperson or a renunciant?
Answer:
They are common to both monastics and laypeople.
The Ornament of the Scriptures Sutra says: Husband and wife, the six relations, may be each other's teachers.
Question:
Third, receiving the precepts in front of a Buddha image, if there is no Buddha image, can one take the precepts by oneself?
Answer:

According to the Sutra of Universal Worthy's Contemplation, one only sincerely invites Shakyamuni to be the preceptor, Manjushri to be the master, Maitreya to be the teacher, all Buddhas to be the witnesses, and all Bodhisattvas to be the fellow students, regardless of whether there are images or not.
Question:
Why is it necessary to receive the precepts, which are a single type of Dharma?
Answer:
It is to show that evil can be suddenly stopped.
Since the precepts take stopping evil as their essence, there is a method of receiving them, in order to suddenly generate the vow.
Good is difficult to produce simultaneously, and the other practices all take cultivating good as their essence, so there is no method of receiving them, because they arise gradually.
Question:
If evil can be suddenly stopped but good cannot be suddenly produced, then delusion can be suddenly extinguished but understanding cannot be suddenly produced.
Answer:
The precepts are the aspect of stopping, and their aspect is quiescent, so there is always the Dharma of precepts.
Evil has the meaning of sudden cessation, while the remaining wholesome [actions] are dynamic characteristics that arise through cultivation, and cannot be cultivated all at once.
Extinguishing delusions and giving rise to understanding are both wholesome practices, so they are not of the same kind as this.
Question:
How is the vow to receive precepts different from receiving precepts from a teacher?
Answer:
If one completes the ritual with a precepts teacher, then they are all received at the same time.
Now, since one gives rise to the thought and speaks, they arise as one gives rise to them, not all at once.
Question:
What merits are gained from bestowing and receiving precepts?
Answer:
The Ornament Scripture says: If one can teach a person to leave home and receive the bodhisattva precepts, it is superior to building eighty-four thousand stupas.
Those who receive the precepts fall into the ranks of bodhisattvas and surpass the suffering of birth and death for three kalpas.
Question:
How is it to receive the precepts and then violate them, compared to not receiving them and not violating them?
Answer:
The Ornament Sutra says, Having precepts and violating them is superior to not having precepts and not violating them.
Having violations is called a bodhisattva, not having violations is called a non-Buddhist.
Question:
The five precepts can be partially received up to fully receiving all five.
How is it for the bodhisattva precepts?
Answer:
The Ornament Sutra says, Among the ten grave precepts, receiving a portion is called a partial bodhisattva, up to two parts, three parts.
If one receives all ten parts, it is called fully receiving the precepts.
Violating the ten grave precepts without regret allows for re-receiving.
The eighty-four thousand subtle precepts are all called light. Violating them allows for repentance. Repenting in front of a hand-like image immediately extinguishes them.
The fourth gate of the characteristics of the essence of the precepts.
The Abhidharma uses form as the essence. The Satyasiddhi ÅšÄstra uses what is neither form nor mind as the essence. The DÄrá¹£á¹­Äntika school uses mind as the essence.
The Ornament Sutra says, The essence of all bodhisattva precepts, whether of ordinary beings or sages, is mind.
If the mind is exhausted, the precepts are exhausted. Since the mind is inexhaustible, the precepts are inexhaustible.
Therefore, beings in the six realms can receive the precepts. As long as they understand language, they can receive and not lose them.
If we rely on the Yingluo Sutra to clarify the essence of the three precepts separately, the precept of restraining evil is the ten pÄramitÄs;
The precept of benefiting beings is loving-kindness, compassion, joy, and equanimity;
The precept of cultivating goodness is the eighty-four thousand Dharma gates.
This takes the four immeasurables as transforming others, so it is the precept of benefiting beings;
The ten perfections are one's own practice, so they are taken as the precept of restraining evil;
The precept of cultivating goodness is common to oneself and others, so the eighty-four thousand Dharma gates are taken as the precept of cultivating goodness.
Fifth, the chapter on the objects of opposition of the precepts.

The great purport of these three kinds of precepts is that there is no evil that is not stopped, no good that is not practiced, and no person that is not liberated. Then the delusions of the five abodes are all the objects of opposition.
However, the essence of the precepts is quiescent goodness. Quiescent abandonment of the evil of things is the precepts for embracing sentient beings;
Quiescent abandonment of the evil of not practicing is the precepts for embracing wholesome dharmas;
Apart from these two, quiescent abandonment of the mind that gives rise to evil is the precepts for embracing discipline.
Therefore, the three precepts separately govern the three delusions.
Moreover, these three precepts practice the evil of the two vehicles' three precepts.
As for embracing discipline, it universally prevents the offenses of the three karmas, while the two vehicles only prevent bodily and verbal [actions].
As for embracing sentient beings, it is the mind that does not abandon things, while the two vehicles practice the conduct of solitary goodness.
As for embracing wholesome dharmas, it vows to practice many wholesome [dharmas], while the two vehicles practice biased and inferior conduct.
Sixth, the gate of performance and non-performance.

One says that it solely uses performed goodness as its essence, second, it solely uses non-performed goodness as its essence, and third, it jointly uses performed and non-performed goodness as its essence.
However, these three precepts both have performance and non-performance. Performance is the vowing mind, and non-performance is the precepts born from the mind that extend to enlightenment.
In the Lesser Vehicle, non-performance is taken as the essence, while the performing mind is always difficult.
The great being takes both. If the precepts are combined with prajÃ±Ä, then the mind precepts are taken as the basis.
Always having the mind, then non-performance is always born.
The seventh is the general and specific aspect.
In general, they are all precepts of restraining the faculties.
All have the function of benefiting beings, and in general they are precepts of gathering sentient beings.
The Treatise on the Stages of Concentration says: The precepts are all general, and the three collections of precepts are collectively called precepts of restraining the faculties.
Within the precepts of restraining the faculties, the other two collections are distinguished, and the remaining precepts are those of restraining the faculties.
Since the precepts of restraining the faculties are general, the other two are also general. However, they are divided into three based on the different intentions for establishing them.
The eighth is the sequence aspect.
The Garland Sutra first clarifies the precepts of good conduct, then the precepts of benefiting sentient beings, and finally the precepts of restraining from wrongdoing.

Moreover, the first clarifies that there is no evil that is not to be stopped, the second clarifies that there is no good that is not to be practiced, and the third clarifies that there is no person who is not to be saved.
The present text clarifies the sequence of the three precepts. First, one must personally stop wrongdoing, so the first clarifies the precepts of restraining from wrongdoing;
then one is able to reach out to others, so the second clarifies the precepts of benefiting sentient beings;

personally practicing and transforming others necessarily involves cultivating goodness, which is common to both personal practice and transforming others, so it clarifies the precepts of good conduct.
The ninth is the chapter on cause and effect.

According to the Compendium of the Great Vehicle, the three precepts are the causes of the three virtues. Stopping all evil is the cause of the virtue of cessation, cultivating all good is the cause of the virtue of wisdom, and saving all sentient beings is the cause of the virtue of kindness.
The first one has no defilement that is not extinguished;ğŸ”½the second one has no virtue that is not complete, which means accomplishing Buddhahood oneself;
the virtue of kindness also enables sentient beings to attain both things, which is others accomplishing Buddhahood.
Therefore, one receives these three precepts.
If oneself and others all become Buddhas, this is the inconceivable vast meaning.
The tenth is the small and large approach.
The Hinayana has no repeated reception, while the Mahayana has repeated reception.
The Hinayana has relinquishing the precepts, while the Mahayana has no relinquishing the precepts.
The Hinayana has a selection of the assembly, while the Mahayana has no selection of the assembly, so even slaves, animals, and those who understand the Buddha's words can receive the precepts.
The Hinayana has two teachers, ten teachers, and twenty teachers, while the Mahayana has only one teacher.
The Hinayana prevents two karmas, while the Mahayana prevents three karmas.
The Hinayana lasts for one lifetime, while the Mahayana lasts until the fruition of Buddhahood.
The Hinayana gradually establishes precepts according to transgressions, while the Mahayana establishes precepts in advance before transgressions occur.
The Hinayana precepts have a fixed number, from ten precepts up to five hundred;
The Mahayana is indefinite, with either six grave precepts, or eight grave precepts and twenty-eight light precepts, or forty-two kinds, or ten grave precepts and forty-eight light precepts.
The differences and similarities are fully discussed in the Nirvana Commentary.
In the text, there are three parts:
The first is the sutra's description of the procedures for receiving the precepts, the second is the actual receiving of the precepts, and the third is requesting testimony to dispel doubts.
The first is the preparatory practices before receiving the precepts, the next is the actual receiving of the precepts, and the last is the preparatory practices.
Combining the three into two:
The first two clearly explain the receiving of the precepts, and the last one clarifies the intention of receiving.
The reason why bodhisattvas receive the precepts is to stop slander and dispel doubts, to make the honored ones respect the Way, and then they can begin to open the teachings and transmit the Dharma.
At that time, ÅšrÄ«mÄlÄ, having heard the prediction, this is receiving the previous prediction.
Respectfully standing describes the procedures for receiving the precepts.
The Buddha is in the sky and ÅšrÄ«mÄlÄ is on the ground. It is to make the words of the sky and earth interact, and the procedures for receiving the Dharma convenient. Therefore, she stands.

Moreover, ÅšrÄ«mÄlÄ bowed to the Buddha and requested the Buddha to accept her. The Buddha then gave her a prophecy. Therefore, she rejoiced upon hearing the prophecy, respectfully stood, and did not wish to stand and receive the precepts.

Moreover, the Buddha gave her a prophecy in front, and she rejoiced upon hearing the prophecy. She was about to receive the precepts, and further adjusted her appearance. She was enlightened in the place, and it was a skillful means for receiving the precepts. Therefore, she stood.
Some say that standing is the appearance of about to act. ÅšrÄ«mÄlÄ was about to receive and practice the precepts. Therefore, she stood.

As for receiving the ten precepts, the upper precept character clarifies the inner mind's ability to receive, and the lower precept character clarifies that the precepts are the Dharma to be received.
It is called receiving because the practitioner preemptively accepts it.
Moreover, it is called receiving because the determined mind embraces it.
Ten is the name of a perfect number.
The Dharma of the bodhisattva precepts is long and extensive. Therefore, it is called great.
World-Honored One, from today onward, the second clarifies the correct reception of the precepts.
The explanations of this are not the same, and there are generally five masters.
Tan Lin says:
From this chapter onwards, there are ten great vows.
However, below there are three separate vows, so it is different from this explanation.
The Fu Shi says:
The first five are to stop evil, and the latter five are to give rise to good, not distinguishing the three precepts.
The third teacher says:
The first precept is general, referring to the mind that vows to receive the precepts and the general prevention of offenses.
From the second onwards, it refers to the mind that vows to receive the precepts and the specific prevention of offenses.
The fourth teacher says:
The first nine are receiving the precepts of worldly teachings, and the last one is attaining the precepts of the true Dharma.
Following the rules and prohibitions is called receiving the precepts of worldly teachings;
Realizing the truth and being free from faults is called attaining the precepts of the true Dharma.

Among the first nine, the first one is receiving the precepts of restraining oneself, the four are receiving the precepts of accumulating good dharmas, and the last four are receiving the precepts of benefiting sentient beings.
The fifth teacher says:
The first five are included in the precepts of restraining oneself, the four are included in benefiting sentient beings, and the last one is included in accumulating good dharmas.
These five are taken and abandoned by the person, but now only the fifth teacher's explanation is used.
Question:
How can it be known that the first is the restraint of the precepts?
Answer:
The first five all clarify the cessation of evil, so they are the restraint of the precepts.
The five are divided into two:
The first one generally clarifies the cessation of evil.

Not giving rise to a mind that violates the precepts means that if one has already received the five precepts and eight precepts, etc., in the past, one now vows in front of the Buddha not to give rise to a mind that violates the precepts.
Moreover, in the past, one only prevented the seven branches, not the mental realm;
Now, one wishes to be all-encompassing, so one does not give rise to a mind that violates the precepts.

If one has never received the precepts in the past, and now vows not to give rise to a mind that violates the precepts, this is receiving the precepts, obtaining the precepts, and upholding the precepts.
As for the precepts that are received, there are two ways of obtaining the precepts:
First, obtaining them from receiving them, which are the precepts that are received;
Second, not obtained through acceptance, referring to the precepts of concentration and the path.
Now it is the acceptance of precepts, meaning to cease all evil, cultivate all good, and deliver all beings.
Not giving rise to a mind of transgression means not giving rise to a mind of evil that is not ceased, not cultivating a mind of good, and not delivering a mind of beings.
Therefore, it is the acceptance of the three, the attainment of the three, and the upholding of the three.
Moreover, the Dharma of precepts has two aspects:
First, acceptance, second, upholding.
But acceptance is easy while upholding is difficult, so the difficult is explained first, and one necessarily attains the easy.
Moreover, since one originally accepts in order to uphold, upholding is the basis of acceptance, so upholding is explained first.
Moreover, upholding necessarily attains the precepts, but acceptance does not necessarily attain them.

Moreover, fearing that people would say that ÅšrÄ«mÄlÄ is a woman of the deep palace, who can accept with momentary courage but may not always uphold in the beginning and end, therefore, now explaining that being able to uphold is precisely the acceptance.
Each precept has three sentences.
The first phrase World-Honored One is requesting the Buddha to bear witness.
Moreover, since the Buddha is the condition for giving rise to precepts, one faces the Buddha.
From this day forth until I attain enlightenment, the second is stating the time for receiving the precepts.
This day clarifies the beginning of upholding the precepts.
Until I attain enlightenment clarifies the end of upholding the precepts.
Wubi Lin says:
The Sanskrit text says 'bodhimanda,' which means the site of enlightenment.
Moreover, it is in contrast to the two vehicles' precepts for the duration of one's life, so it clarifies the long duration.
In the precepts I have received, the third is clarifying the receiving of the precepts.
Previously, it distinguished the long duration, now it clarifies the extensive prevention, both of which are different from the two vehicles.
The MahÄprajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ-sÅ«tra says, If there is body, speech, and mind, then this is the coarse karma of a bodhisattva, and it is also a violation of the precepts.
Now, knowing that the three karmas are unborn, therefore the mind of transgression does not arise, revealing the high status of ÅšrÄ«mÄlÄ.
World-Honored One, from today onward, the second set of four precepts specifically prevents four evils.
Now this is the precept of not being disrespectful, stopping the evil of being disrespectful.
The teacher is the honored one, elder brothers and sisters are the elders.
Moreover, just this year's high virtue and excellence are the honored elders.

Disrespect is likened to a high mountain, the water of the Dharma does not abide. Therefore, not being disrespectful to the honored ones, the mind does not disrespect in serving the honored elders, the honored elders then obtain the Dharma's instructions, fully as explained in the precepts, the bhiká¹£us cannot be taught the Dharma while standing.
Third, not giving rise to an angry mind towards any sentient being, also obtaining the above not being disrespectful to the superior, and here not being angry towards the inferior.
Moreover, the previous specifically clarifies not being disrespectful to the superior, now comprehensively discerning not giving rise to an angry mind towards all sentient beings.
This comprehensively and specifically mutually obtain the two texts.
The bodhisattva takes transforming beings as the foremost, if giving rise to an angry mind then it obstructs beings, therefore it is removed.
Question:
What kind of mind is it to not give rise to an angry mind towards sentient beings?
Answer:

It is a mind of loving-kindness and compassion, because one who gives rise to an angry mind towards sentient beings has no loving-kindness, and because the wholesome root of non-hatred is the essence of loving-kindness and compassion.

The Diamond Immortal Treatise Master explains the four immeasurables, saying that the essence of the mind of loving-kindness and compassion is the wholesome root of non-hatred, because it is the antidote to the dharma of hatred.
Question:
What kind of hatred does loving-kindness and compassion treat?
Answer:ğŸ”½Hatred towards those who can be hated is treated by loving-kindness;
hatred towards those who cannot be hated is treated by compassion.
Moreover, the mind of killing sentient beings is treated by loving-kindness, and the mind of beating sentient beings is called compassion.
Moreover, the Nirvana Sutra says: Hatred is of two kinds:
one is superior and the other is middling.
Cultivating loving-kindness eliminates the superior, and cultivating compassion eliminates the middling.
Moreover, hatred is of two kinds:
one has causes and conditions, and the other does not have causes and conditions.
The compassionate mind cuts off causes and conditions for existence, while the compassionate mind cuts off causes and conditions for non-existence.
Some scholars say:
Cultivating compassion is to eliminate sentient beings' awareness of anger, cultivating compassion is to eliminate sentient beings' awareness of vexation.
Fourth, not giving rise to jealous thoughts towards others' physical bodies and external possessions refers to the immeasurable joy.
Because those who envy others have no joyful love in their minds, we know that being free from jealousy is the joyful mind.
Physical bodies refer to internal good rewards and external wonderful fruits.

As a bodhisattva, one should originally give to beings internal and external good fruits, but now others obtain them by themselves, one should give rise to rejoicing, how could one further give rise to jealous thoughts?
Fifth, the precept not giving rise to stingy thoughts towards internal and external dharmas - Lin Gong says:
One's own wealth is internal, and others' wealth is external, the Sanskrit text says so.
Some people say:
Internal refers to one's own body, external refers to one's wife, children, and possessions.
Bodhisattvas make vows for the sake of sentient beings and accept bodies, wives, children, and possessions.
Now sentient beings come to take the inner and outer things, then they meet with the bodhisattvas.
Lin Gong said:
Not giving rise to a stingy mind is immeasurable giving.
The Diamond Immortal Treatise Master explains:
The essence of the mind of giving is the wholesome root of non-greed.
Question:
The mind of giving treats greed, and the contemplation of impurity treats greed. What is the difference between these two?
Answer:
The contemplation of impurity can treat attachment to the form of others, while the mind of giving can treat attachment to sexual desire.
Here it is explained that a stingy mind cannot give, and a greedy mind also cannot give. Therefore, one who can give must break through stinginess and greed.

The sutras and treatises explain the four immeasurables differently. Some say that great compassion removes suffering, great kindness bestows happiness, the joyful mind rejoices in the previous liberation from suffering and attainment of happiness, and seeing the other person liberated from suffering and attaining happiness, one's mind lets go.
Now, these four are combined into two pairs, called respecting superiors without arrogance, and pitying inferiors without anger, not being jealous of others, and not being stingy with oneself.
Question:
Why does the original life first clarify non-arrogance?
Answer:
Since ÅšrÄ«mÄlÄ currently holds a high position, she often gives rise to arrogant thoughts.
Since she clarifies non-arrogance first, the ancient books say, Not being arrogant when above.
Since she is not arrogant towards superiors, she may give rise to anger towards inferiors, so she clarifies non-anger.
Moreover, if one is arrogant, one will not accept the transformation of others, and thus oneself will not become a Buddha;
If one is angry, one will not transform others, and thus others will not become Buddhas. The faults are great indeed.
Therefore, the original life first distinguishes them.
Question:
Why does one clarify non-stinginess and non-jealousy after arrogance and anger?
Answer:

The former two are afflictions, and the latter two are entanglements. Afflictions are heavier than entanglements, so one first gets rid of the heavy and then stops the light. Thus, all evils are completely extinguished.
Question:
Since there are ten entanglements, why are only two of them specifically mentioned as to be abandoned?
Answer:
Jealousy is the cause of being lowly and mean, while stinginess is the karma of being poor. Great beings should be respected and lead others, so they should abandon these.
Moreover, stinginess is not giving others wealth, while jealousy is begrudging others' happiness. These are the basis for obstructing kindness, so they are specifically mentioned as to be abandoned.
Furthermore, asuras are stingy with form and jealous of taste, while Indra is stingy with taste and jealous of form. Therefore, the nine knots are formed based on these.
Bodhisattvas, in contrast to this, specifically speak of abandoning them.
Question:
Since the first precept is general, why are four specific precepts of not being arrogant, not being angry, not being jealous, and not being stingy separately mentioned?
Answer:
Some say it is because these four are serious.
In the Treatise on the Stages of Concentration Practice, these four are said to be pÄrÄjika offenses.
The Treatise on the Stages of Concentration Practice clarifies four dharmas, the fourth being a deluded mind, which is the first arrogance in this text.

The second of the present [four] corresponds to the third of the BodhisattvabhÅ«mi, which is the mind of anger;ğŸ”½The third of the present [four] corresponds to the first of the BodhisattvabhÅ«mi, which is the mind of greed;

World-Honored One, from today until I attain enlightenment, I will not hoard wealth for my own sake. This second part clarifies the four precepts, which are the precepts for gathering sentient beings.

As for the four precepts, the first precept specifically clarifies using wealth to gather sentient beings, the second precept generally clarifies using the four means of gathering to gather sentient beings, the third precept rescues sentient beings from the suffering of the present world, and the fourth precept cuts off the causes of sentient beings' suffering.
The four precepts form two pairs. The first two prevent one's own evil, while the latter two prevent abandoning others' evil.

The first two prohibitions are for one's own sake, the first clarifying not doing for oneself to receive the fruit of happiness, the next clarifying not doing for oneself to practice the causes of happiness.

The latter two prohibitions are for abandoning the evil of others, the first clarifying not abandoning things and further receiving the fruit of suffering, the latter clarifying not abandoning things and practicing the causes of suffering.

The first text is in two parts:

Whatever is received and below, the second clarifies benefiting beings.
Question:
Why does a bodhisattva not accumulate wealth for the body?
Answer:
Accumulating wealth for the body only brings happiness to oneself;
accumulating wealth for others brings happiness to all.
Moreover, accumulating wealth for oneself does not give rise to goodness;
accumulating wealth for others constantly gives rise to effortless [goodness].
Moreover, accumulating wealth for the body belongs to the five families;
accumulating wealth for others belongs to oneself.
Moreover, if one accumulates wealth for oneself, one cannot have constant wealth;
if one accumulates wealth for others, one can obtain constant wealth for oneself.
Furthermore, if one accumulates wealth for oneself, one will increase greed and stinginess;
if one accumulates wealth for others, one will know contentment and have few desires.

In the second precept, it is also divided into two parts:
The first clarifies not acting for one's own sake but practicing the four means of gathering disciples.
For the sake of all sentient beings is the second, practicing the four means of gathering disciples for the sake of all sentient beings.

Practicing the four means of gathering disciples is originally for the sake of others. Why is it said that one does not practice the four means of gathering disciples for one's own sake?
Answer:
There are bodhisattvas who, although they practice the four means of gathering disciples, use the wholesome to return to themselves;
Therefore, now it is clarified that practicing the four means of gathering disciples for the sake of others means using the wholesome to give to others.

Question:

Answer:
Above, giving was specifically clarified. Now, the four means of conversion are generally discussed.
Moreover, above, giving was simply clarified to rescue from the suffering of immediate distress;
In the giving within the four means of conversion, [the bodhisattva] converts [others] and causes them to abide in the principle [of reality].
Therefore, [the giving within the four means of conversion] is different [from the giving discussed above].
With a mind free from defiled attachment means that when practicing the four means of conversion to convert sentient beings, one often gives rise to a mind of attachment;
[The bodhisattva] causes [others] to know that both the one who converts and the one who is converted are empty, and thus does not give rise to defiled attachment.
With a mind of inexhaustible contentment means that from now until the end of time, [the bodhisattva] always practices the four means of conversion, and thus is inexhaustible and content.
With an unobstructed mind means that when practicing the four means of conversion, [the bodhisattva] treats friends and enemies equally.
Moreover, being free from defiled attachment means that when practicing the four means of conversion, [the bodhisattva] does not give rise to attachment towards friends.
No dissatisfaction means not being lazy towards ordinary people.
Unimpeded mind means not being obstructed towards those one dislikes.
By being free from these three, one is able to embrace the four forms of birth.
World-Honored One, from today onwards, if I see an orphan... This is the third, extracting the suffering of sentient beings.

Those without parents are made to have parents, those without attendants are made to have children, and so on, up to those in distress are made to attain peace and happiness.

World-Honored One, from today onward, the fourth is eliminating the causes of suffering.
Or it may be that the previous [two precepts] are for eliminating present suffering, and this one is for eliminating future suffering.

Although there are four precepts, they do not go beyond compassion. The first two precepts are great kindness in bestowing happiness, and the latter two precepts are great compassion in eliminating suffering.
In bestowing happiness, the first one bestows present happiness, and the next one bestows future happiness.

Moreover, the first one bestows the fruit of happiness, and the latter one bestows the cause of happiness.
In the precepts of great compassion, there are also two. The first one eliminates present suffering, and the latter one eliminates future suffering.

Therefore, the following sections on subduing and embracing clarify worldly and transcendent benefits. Therefore, it is known that it completely alleviates all suffering.

Catching birds is called catching.

If sentient beings change their evil ways and cultivate goodness, they will then attract the Buddha to appear in the world and turn the wheel of the Dharma.
Turning the wheel of the Dharma means knowing suffering, cutting off the cause of suffering, realizing cessation, and cultivating the path.

And being able to turn along with it means that the Buddha now has already transformed others, and those others rely on the Buddha's teachings to practice, and they too can see suffering, cut off the cause of suffering, realize cessation, and cultivate the path. Next, the four sentences are combined into three:

Due to engaging in evil and violating the precepts, the true Dharma is destroyed and evil destinies increase, obstructing the arising of the undefiled.
In order to make them abandon evil, the Dharma can then long endure, humans and gods increase, and they are ultimately placed in the holy fruits.
Seeing this benefit means seeing sentient beings attaining worldly benefits and supramundane benefits, and therefore engaging in the activities of subduing and embracing.
World-Honored One, from today onward explains this one precept differently.

The principle of the true reality of all dharmas is called the true Dharma.
Realizing the Dharma in the mind is called embracing.

If we discuss these in terms of stages, forgetting the Great Vehicle refers to forgetting the fruition of Buddhahood.
